question: 4 (d)
sols_html:
The formula for the Laplacian matrix L is

\[\begin{aligned} L = D^{T} R^{-1} D\end{aligned}\]

But we can simply calculate the Laplacian matrix by computing the following:

For the diagonal entries (\(L_{ii}\))

\[\begin{aligned} L_{ii} = \sum_{connected \ edges, i} \gamma_{i}\end{aligned}\]

For the non-diagonal edges (\(L_{ij}\))

\[\begin{aligned} L_{ij} = \sum_{shared \ edges j} \gamma_{j}\end{aligned}\]

if there are shared edges and \(L_{ij} = 0\) if no shared edges

\(\gamma = \frac{1}{R}\) Where R is the resistance of the edge. which in this question \(R = 1\) so \(\gamma = 1\).

Following the equations given above, the Laplacian matrix is

\[\begin{aligned} L = \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -1 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 0\\ -1 & 4 & -1 & 0 & -1 & -1\\ -1 & -1 & 4 & -1 & 0 & -1\\ -1& 0 & -1 & 4 & -1 & -1\\ -1& -1 & 0 & -1 & 4 & -1\\ 0 & -1 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

The columns of matrix L are labeled as node 1 to 6 from left to right.

FINAL ANSWER

\(L = \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -1 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 0\\ -1 & 4 & -1 & 0 & -1 & -1\\ -1 & -1 & 4 & -1 & 0 & -1\\ -1& 0 & -1 & 4 & -1 & -1\\ -1& -1 & 0 & -1 & 4 & -1\\ 0 & -1 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\)
sols_raw:
The formula for the Laplacian matrix L is: <math>L = D^{T} R^{-1} D</math>

But we can simply calculate the Laplacian matrix by computing the following:

For the diagonal entries (<math>L_{ii}</math>): <math>L_{ii} = \sum_{connected \ edges, i} \gamma_{i}</math>

For the non-diagonal edges (<math>L_{ij}</math>): <math>L_{ij} = \sum_{shared \ edges j} \gamma_{j}</math> if there are shared edges and <math>L_{ij} = 0 </math> if no shared edges

<math>\gamma = \frac{1}{R}</math> Where R is the resistance of the edge. which in this question <math>R = 1</math> so <math>\gamma = 1</math>.

Following the equations given above, the Laplacian matrix is: <math>L = \begin{bmatrix}
4 & -1 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 0\\ 
-1 & 4 & -1 & 0 & -1 & -1\\ 
-1 & -1 & 4 & -1 & 0 & -1\\ 
-1& 0 & -1 & 4 & -1 & -1\\ 
-1& -1 & 0 & -1 & 4 & -1\\ 
0 & -1 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 4
\end{bmatrix}</math>

The columns of matrix L are labeled as node 1 to 6 from left to right.

FINAL ANSWER

<math>L = \begin{bmatrix}
4 & -1 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 0\\ 
-1 & 4 & -1 & 0 & -1 & -1\\ 
-1 & -1 & 4 & -1 & 0 & -1\\ 
-1& 0 & -1 & 4 & -1 & -1\\ 
-1& -1 & 0 & -1 & 4 & -1\\ 
0 & -1 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 4
\end{bmatrix}</math>
statement_html:
Consider a network arranged in the shape of an octahedron as in this diagram:

The nodes have been labeled with the large numbers and 3 of the edges (resistors) have been given orientations and labeled with small numbers. Assume all resistances are equal to 1. Let D be the incidence matrix (for some choice of labeling and arrows for the remaining edges) and let L be the Laplacian.

(d) Write down the Laplacian L.

statement_raw:
Consider a network arranged in the shape of an octahedron as in this diagram:

:[[File:MATH307 April 2012 Question 04.png|300px]]

The nodes have been labeled with the large numbers and 3 of the edges (resistors) have been given orientations and labeled with small numbers. Assume all resistances are equal to 1. Let ''D'' be the incidence matrix (for some choice of labeling and arrows for the remaining edges) and let ''L'' be the Laplacian.

'''(d)''' Write down the Laplacian ''L''.
